word:
The Importance of So-called 
       "Common Branches" 


     I was talking with one of the teachers of our school at Fernando, in southern California; and he told me that some had come to this school with diplomas showing that they had taken some of the higher studies in other schools. "Did you examine every such student," I inquired, "to find out whether he had received the proper instruction in these branches?" "Why," said the teacher, "we could give the students no credit for the work done in the past, as represented by the diplomas. Their training even in the common branches had been very defective."
